name: Sabudana Khichdi
history: Sabudana Khichdi is a traditional Indian dish commonly consumed during Hindu fasting periods. It originates from the state of Maharashtra but is popular across India.
description: Sabudana Khichdi is a savory dish made from tapioca pearls (sabudana), typically seasoned with spices, peanuts, and sometimes potatoes. It's light yet filling and often eaten during fasting days.

equipment.name: skillet
equipment.description: A pan used for sautÃ©ing and cooking the khichdi.

equipment.name: spatula
equipment.description: Used for stirring and mixing ingredients.

instructions.title: Soak Sabudana
instructions.description: Wash the sabudana under cold water until water runs clear. Soak it in water for 3-4 hours, or until the pearls swell up and turn soft.

instructions.title: Roast Peanuts
instructions.description: Dry roast peanuts in a skillet until they are crunchy. Cool them and coarsely grind.

instructions.title: Prepare the Khichdi
instructions.description: Heat ghee or oil in a skillet. Add cumin seeds, curry leaves, and chopped green chili. SautÃ© for a minute. Add diced potato and cook until tender. Add the soaked sabudana, roasted peanuts, salt, and sugar. Mix well and cook until the sabudana pearls become translucent.

instructions.title: Garnish and Serve
instructions.description: Turn off the heat, add lemon juice, and mix. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves. Serve hot.

tips: Ensure the sabudana is soaked well, but not mushy.
Stir frequently while cooking to avoid sticking.
variations: Add vegetables like green peas or carrots for a nutritious twist.
For a spicy version, increase the quantity of green chilies.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh, but can be refrigerated for up to 1 day.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container and reheat before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in a microwave or on a stovetop with a little ghee.
presentationTips: Serve with a side of yogurt or fresh coconut chutney.
